details.description: If your business pays the cost of an employee's home phone - what you must report to HMRC and what taxes and National Insurance are due
details.alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting if you pay for an employee's home phone

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
As an employer paying your employees’ home phone expenses, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

Expenses can include:

  • telephone line rental
  • business-related call charges
  • private call charges

parts.title: What's exempt
parts.body:
You don’t have to report anything to HMRC or pay tax and National Insurance if the telephone is only for business use and either of the following apply:

  • you arrange and pay for the telephone
  • your employee arranges the phone but you pay the supplier directly, and your employee earns less than a rate of £8,500 a year

You reimburse your employee’s business call charges

If your employee earns at a rate of less than £8,500 a year, you don’t have to report anything or deduct and pay PAYE tax or National Insurance.

parts.title: What to report and pay
parts.body:
If telephone expenses aren’t exempt, you must report them to HMRC and may have to deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on them.

You can apply for a dispensation, which means you won’t have to include telephone expenses for employees on your end-of-year reports.

You arrange and pay for the phone

Who gets the benefit What to do What to deduct or pay
Employees at a rate of £8,500 or more a year Report on form P11D, section K Class 1A National Insurance
Directors Report on form P11D, section K Class 1A National Insurance

Your employee arranges the phone contract but you pay the supplier

Who gets the benefit What to do What to deduct or pay
Employees at a rate of less than £8,500 a year Report on form P9D, section A(2) Class 1 National Insurance through payroll
Employees at a rate of £8,500 or more a year Report on form P11D, section B Class 1 National Insurance through payroll
Directors Report on form P11D, section B Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

Your employee arranges the phone contract but you reimburse them

If your employee earns at a rate of £8,500 or more a year, or if they’re a director:

What you reimburse What to do What to deduct or pay
Rental and/or private call charges Add the amount you reimburse to the employee’s earnings Class 1 National Insurance and PAYE tax through payroll
Business call charges Report on form P11D, section N Nothing

parts.title: Work out the value
parts.body:
The value to use depends on who arranges the employee’s telephone line.

If you arrange the telephone, the value for reporting and National Insurance is the total cost of line rental and all call charges (business and private).

If your employee arranges the telephone but you pay the supplier

Who gets the benefit Value to report Value to pay National Insurance on
Employees at a rate of less than £8,500 a year Cost of line rental plus private call charges only Cost of line rental plus private call charges only
Employees at a rate of £8,500 or more a year Cost of line rental plus all call charges (private and business) Cost of line rental plus private call charges only
Directors Cost of line rental plus all call charges (private and business) Cost of line rental plus private call charges only
